text.p: Recall that [mathjaxinline]C[0,1][/mathjaxinline] is the vector space of continuous functions on the interval [mathjaxinline][0,1][/mathjaxinline], and that we have an inner product on that vector space given by [mathjaxinline]\langle f, g \rangle = \int _0^1 f(t)g(t) \ dt[/mathjaxinline].
Let [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] be the subspace of [mathjaxinline]C[0,1][/mathjaxinline] which is the span of a single function, [mathjaxinline]f(t) = t[/mathjaxinline].
Let [mathjaxinline]g(t) = t^2[/mathjaxinline]. What is the orthogonal projection of [mathjaxinline]g[/mathjaxinline] onto [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]?

font.p: Again, we have an orthogonal basis of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline], namely [mathjaxinline]\{ f\}[/mathjaxinline]. So we use the projection formula: the function that we seek is

tr.td: [mathjax]\frac{\langle g, f \rangle }{\langle f, f \rangle } f = \frac{\int _0^1 t^3 \ dt}{\int _0^1 t^2 \ dt}t= \frac{1/4}{1/3}t = \frac{3}{4}t.[/mathjax]
